body: Then I'm not planning this right now - compilation speed is more important to me right now. Maybe some fancy sed script can do this job some later time.

@nlohmann It's doesn't affect compilation speed.
Doctest compiles on Linux GCC Release in 3.20 sec while Catch compiles in 15.62 sec.
I know. That's why changing macros to work with `DOCTEST_CONFIG_SUPER_FAST_ASSERTS` has no priority for me.
@Slavjan Can you please open an issue at https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/new?
What was wrong with the enum? I find it clearer than booleans. Also, `vector<bool>` is quite special, do we really want to use it?

I made some experiments with deeply nested inputs and wanted to save memory. A vector of an enum with two elements may be cleaner, but - when properly documented - a bool can do the same. Or did I miss anything?

Hmm, the memory saving makes a lot of sense. We just have to be careful to a few caveats.

After re-reading this great [article](https://howardhinnant.github.io/onvectorbool.html), I guess that as long as we don't go heavy on algorithms, it should not have a negative run-time performance impact.
Yes, we only use push_back(), pop_back(), and back().
Shouldn't that be `typename IteratorType::value_type`? Or did I misunderstand the point of this class?
Yes, `value_type`, `pointer`, and `reference` refer to the thing that the iterator references, not the iterator itself.

Changing `value_type` to `typename IteratorType::value_type` and adjusting the result yields the same error message.

And idea of the iterator is to return something where I can call `key()` and `value()` on - so wouldn't be `typename IteratorType::value_type` just the type of `value()`?
Ah, didn't notice that `operator*` return type was the same type as the class.

Hmm in that case I think you should add `iteration_proxy_internal` to the `is_basic_json_nested_type` trait in `detail/meta.hpp`.

I'm kinda shooting in the dark here, but this error message reminds me of it.

With that, I get a different error message:

I think it would be better to make it a partial specialization, to handle `basic_json<...>`
How would that look like?

```cpp
NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
inline void swap<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL>(NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL& j1, NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL&j2);
```

Did not try it out though, so might fail miserably to compile
I'll try.

I tried

```cpp
NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
inline void swap<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL>(NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL& j1, NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL& j2) noexcept(
    is_nothrow_move_constructible<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL>::value and
    is_nothrow_move_assignable<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL>::value
)
```

and got

```
 error: function template partial specialization is not allowed
inline void swap<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL>(NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL& j1, NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL& j2) noexcept(
            ^   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```
I'll give it a try tomorrow (on phone)
No worries!
Well, I forgot that function partial specialization is forbidden, nevermind!
very good
I love how you're still going strong with the emoji's.
I also convinced my colleagues at work to use Gitmoji for their projects ;-)
